PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [c7cc3805d5](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19068/commits/c7cc3805d5f0d8a2a14a7673d3441f923fbd6c3e)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.UniformSpace.Dini` (new file)|1262|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ OrderDual.instContinuousInv`
`+ OrderDual.instTopologicalGroup`
`+ OrderDual.instUniformSpace`
`+ tendsto_of_antitone_of_pointwise`
`+ tendsto_of_monotone_of_pointwise`
`++ tendstoLocallyUniformlyOn_of_forall_tendsto`
`++ tendstoLocallyUniformly_of_forall_tendsto`
`++ tendstoUniformlyOn_of_forall_tendsto`
`++ tendstoUniformly_of_forall_tendsto`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#19098~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
Thanks a lot!

Since `G` is linearly ordered, `OrderClosedTopology G` comes for free.

I have thought about removing the linearity assumption, but my mind is not clear yet about it, I'll add more once it is the case.

I have a bunch of variants of the statement to suggest, not all of which are necessarily interesting right now.
- I think it would be nice to first state the [TendstoLocallyUniformly](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/UniformSpace/UniformConvergence.html#TendstoLocallyUniformly) (or maybe even [TendstoUniformlyOnFilter](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/UniformSpace/UniformConvergence.html#TendstoUniformlyOnFilter)) statement, which completely gets rid of the compactness assumption. Then this result comes for free thanks to [tendstoLocallyUniformly_iff_tendstoUniformly_of_compactSpace](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/UniformSpace/UniformConvergence.html#tendstoLocallyUniformly_iff_tendstoUniformly_of_compactSpace)
- I think you can just immediately replace `SemilatticeSup G` by [IsDirected](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Directed.html#IsDirected)
- In the same vein, one could add a version of the statement about infimas of directed families, instead of limits. I'm not sure this one should be added right now, but I mention it in case you think it should.

+ ~~I don't think we can get rid of compactness, but maybe I'm wrong.~~ done
+ I switched to `IsDirected`
+ I'm not so sure this is valuable, because you would need to assume that your group `G` is complete in some sense. You don't get `h_tendsto` for free by replacing `f` with `â¨† n, F n`. Or have I misunderstood what you mean?
(I forgot to answer the last point : indeed this is what I had in mind you need some hypothesis like that)
This gets nitpicky, but here I would state this assuming only `TopologicalGroup G`, since the statement makes sense in that setting (of course in the proof you go back to the uniform case)

I played a bit with this (feel free to not fully adopt my suggestion if there's some bits you don't like).
```suggestion
  simp_rw [Metric.tendstoLocallyUniformly_iff, dist_eq_norm']
  intro Îµ Îµ_pos x
  simp_rw +singlePass [tendsto_iff_norm_sub_tendsto_zero] at h_tendsto
  obtain âŸ¨n, hnâŸ© := (h_tendsto x).eventually (eventually_lt_nhds Îµ_pos) |>.exists
  refine âŸ¨{y | â€–F n y - f yâ€– < Îµ}, âŸ¨isOpen_lt (by fun_prop) continuous_const |>.mem_nhds hn, ?_âŸ©âŸ©
  have mono : Monotone (fun i => {y | â€–F i y - f yâ€– < Îµ}) := by
    intro n m hnm x hx
    refine norm_le_norm_of_abs_le_abs ?_ |>.trans_lt hx
    simp only [abs_of_nonpos (sub_nonpos_of_le (F_le_f _ _)), neg_sub, sub_le_sub_iff_left]
    exact hF_mono hnm x
  filter_upwards [eventually_ge_atTop n] with m hnm z hz
  exact mono hnm hz
```
The key change is to use more API from normed/metric spaces (in particular, no more `TopologicalAddGroup.tendstoLocallyUniformly_iff`). This allows you to get rid of the case disjunction on `G`. 

Then I also replaced some "continuity of `F n - f`" arguments by continuity of `fun y â†¦ â€–F n y - f yâ€–` to turn balls into inequalities, but this is mostly a matter of taste/golfing.
In fact maybe the lat `have` can just be inlined

Turns out you can remove *both* directedness and nonemptyness by casing on triviality of `atTop` like this:
```
rcases (atTop : Filter Î¹).eq_or_neBot with h | _
  Â· simp only [h, tendstoLocallyUniformly_iff_forall_tendsto, bot_prod, tendsto_bot, implies_true]
```
(This would be even shorter if we had `tendstoLocallyUniformly_bot`)

```suggestion
    refine ge_of_tendsto (h_tendsto x) ?_
```
Can't do this because of `Monotone.ge_of_tendsto`, which should be protected.
Well actually with the current imports there seems to be no issue!

Could you add
```lean
lemma tendstoLocallyUniformlyOn_of_forall_tendsto {s : Set Î±}
    (hF_cont : âˆ€ i, ContinuousOn (F i) s) (hF_mono : âˆ€ x âˆˆ s, Monotone (F Â· x))
    (hf : ContinuousOn f s) (h_tendsto : âˆ€ x âˆˆ s, Tendsto (F Â· x) atTop (ð“ (f x))) :
    TendstoLocallyUniformlyOn F f atTop s := by
  rw [tendstoLocallyUniformlyOn_iff_tendstoLocallyUniformly_comp_coe]
  exact tendstoLocallyUniformly_of_forall_tendsto (hF_cont Â· |>.restrict) 
    (fun _ _ h x â†¦ hF_mono _ x.2 h) hf.restrict (fun x â†¦ h_tendsto x x.2)
```
and then do
```suggestion
    TendstoUniformlyOn F f atTop s := 
  tendstoLocallyUniformlyOn_iff_tendstoUniformlyOn_of_compact hs |>.mp <|
    tendstoLocallyUniformlyOn_of_forall_tendsto hF_cont hF_mono hf h_tendsto
```
?

```suggestion
We generalize the codomain from `â„` to a normed lattice additive commutative group `G`.
```

```suggestion
```

This part is no longer needed.

Dini's theorem is preserved under taking finite products, right? By which I mean if it holds in `Î±` and in `Î²` then it also holds in `Î± Ã— Î²`. This seems to point out that there is a generality that includes both normed lattice groups and linear ordered topological groups. My naÃ¯ve guess for this generality is lattice ordered topological groups.

I don't mean to block the PR on this, but I do want to hear your thoughts on why Dini is wrong/hard to prove in this generality

I'm completely ready to believe there is a good generalization, but it's not obvious to me, probably because I don't really know what are the right analogues of [OrderTopology](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Order/Basic.html#OrderTopology) in the non-linearly-ordered setting (I know for sure that working with open intervals is bad, and I think the version with closed intervals still behaves badly sometimes, e.g it's still not stable under products unless there are top and bottom elements).

What we really need in our proof is a basis of neighborhoods of zero which is stable under having smaller absolute value. We achieve this in our setting thanks to [norm_le_norm_of_abs_le_abs](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Order/Lattice.html#norm_le_norm_of_abs_le_abs), and in the order topology case it's obvious. What is the precise generality you have in mind ?

Well, I'm not entirely sure what you mean by a "lattice ordered topological group." If you mean a lattice ordered group with a topology that makes it into a topological group, then I think that's insufficient (but it's possible I'm wrong here!). You need something which characterizes the topology. The usual natural choice for this would be `OrderTopology`, but for the most part that is only good for linear orders.

In particular, you need some sort of neighborhood basis for the identity consisting of open sets which are solid. In the case of *linearly* ordered topological groups, we have [nhds_basis_Ioo](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Order/Basic.html#nhds_basis_Ioo). In particular, if `0 â‰¤ f â‰¤ g`, then we have `g â»Â¹' (Set.Ioo l u) âŠ† f â»Â¹' (Set.Ioo l u)`, where `l < 0 < u`.

In the case of `NormedLatticeAddCommGroup`, the balls are solid, and so we get a similar monotonicity fact for a neighborhood basis of the identity. So that's essentially the generality in which it holds: it's a topological group in which there is a neighborhood basis of the identity consisting of open sets for which `g â»Â¹' s âŠ† f â»Â¹' s` whenever `0 â‰¤ f â‰¤ g` and `s` lies in this basis.
I see. Can you turn a combination of both your answers into an extra comment in the module doc?
Will do, but I might not get to it until tomorrow.

pullRequest.title: feat: prove Dini's theorem for uniform convergence
